Ottawa, August 24, 1926.

Gentlemen:

Your quotation of the 20th instant for the supplying of the desks required for the use of the Wikwemikong Indian Day School is accepted.

We are requesting Mr. Agent Lewis, Manitouining, to furnish you at once with proper shipping directions, and as soon as you hear from him I would ask that you make shipment of the following desks:

- 12 - $2 Globe #101 Steel Single Desks,
- 4 - $2 Rear,
- 2 - $3 Fronts,

These desks should be supplied at the aggregate price quoted by you, viz., $172.50. These desks should match those previously supplied this school.

In our letter of the 19th instant asking you to quote, the "12 Single Desks, No. 21," should have read "12 Single Desks, No. 2."

After shipment has been made, please forward your account, in duplicate, to Mr. R. J. Lewis, Indian Agent, Manitouining, Ont., as it is necessary that it be certified by him before payment is made.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

F. H. Paget,
Accountant & Purchasing Agent.

The Globe Furniture Co., Ltd.,
Waterloo,
Ont.
19-6-5.

Ottawa, August 24, 1926.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that we are today placing an order with the Globe Furniture Co., Ltd., Waterloo, Ont., to supply the following desks to complete the seating equipment at the Wikwemikong Indian Day School:

- 12 - $2 Single School Desks,
- 4 - $3 Rear,
- 2 - $3 Fronts,
- 2 - $3

Please furnish the above mentioned firm at once with definite shipping instructions.

This firm will also forward their account, in duplicate, to you, and on receipt of the desks, if in good condition, you should certify the account and send it to the Department in order that payment can be made.

When these desks arrive, you should arrange to have them assembled and set up in the classroom.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

R. J. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Manitowaning, Ont.
Mr. J. H. Paget, Asst. & Purchasing Agent,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Ref. 19-6-5

We thank you for your letter of August the 24th giving us order for school desks for the Wikwemikong Indian Day School.

Just as soon as we receive shipping instructions from Mr. Lewis, Indian Agent, Manitowaning, the desks will be shipped at once.

We will invoice the desks as requested in your letter.

Again thanking you, we are,

Yours very truly,

THE GLOBE FURNITURE CO., LIMITED,

B. Skelton
Sales Dept.

August 26th, 1926.

Sir,

I have the honour to enclose herewith a voucher in my favour amounting to $48.93 for payments made for labour performed and articles furnished in connection with the Wikwemikong Day School.

It would appear that the expense in connection with this school is heavy, but all the work performed and articles furnished was necessary. The fence around the building is old and requires repairs every spring before the garden plot can be planted. The garden had to be put in shape for planting and the toilets cleansed. The linseed oil furnished is used on the class-room floors after being scrubbed.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

I have the honour to report that on visiting the Wikwemikong School recently I found that the teacher in the senior class-room is in need of a daily register. Miss Fox claims to have written the Department for a register but did not receive it.

Upon making an examination of the cellar under the school building I found it in a very unsanitary condition as all the filthy water from the kitchen sink drains underneath the building. A tile drain should be installed in order to carry this stagnant water away.

A number of the storm windows require some new glass and should have a coat of paint in order to protect them from the weather.

The stoves, pipes and chimneys require cleaning before the winter sets in, also the storm windows put on.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, October 27th, 1926.

Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 23rd instant with reference to the Sinnemahong Bay School, I beg to say that you may have the storm windows repaired and painted. The stove pipes and chimney should be cleaned.

Regarding the tile drain which you state is necessary to carry away the stagnant water, you may have this installed provided the cost will not be excessive.

Two Registers were sent to the teacher last week.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Mohan,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

R. J. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Ont.

EXTRACT FROM INSPECTOR LEWIS' NOVEMBER REPORT,
on the Wikwemikong Day School.

"Six padlocks and six hasps should be furnished for use of the toilet doors in order to keep them locked when not in use."
Ottawa, November 29th, 1926.

Sir:

Referring to that portion of your report on your inspection of the Wikwemikong Indian Day School for the current month in which you state that 6 padlocks and 6 hasps should be furnished for the use of the doors on the toilets, in order to keep them locked when not in use, I beg to say that you may arrange for the purchase and installation of these locks. Keys should be secured and placed in the care of the teacher. She should see that these toilets are locked when not in use.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

R. J. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Manitoulin Island,
Ont.
Indian Office, Manitoba,

November 27th, 1936.

Sir:

Referring to the last paragraph of Official Letter No. 19-6-5A of September 30th, 1935, in which the Separate School Inspector recommends that a cheap buffet be supplied to the Wikwemikong school in which to store dishes and linen; I have the honour to report that Miss Fox, the principal, has been supplied with a buffet which will cost $28.50 for sale by the T. Eaton Company of Toronto.

As there is not any suitable place at this school to store linen there should be some sort of a buffet or chest of drawers furnished for this purpose and if the Department considers the price of this one not too high the same will be purchased.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Ottawa, August 27, 1928.

SIR:

It has been suggested that it might be an advantage to heat the Wikwemikong Indian Day School by hot air furnaces. It appears that there are five separate stoves used in keeping the classrooms and teacher's residence heated and that it might be even an economy to effect a change. I should be grateful if you could get a price on a hot air furnace, installed with the necessary piping to the rooms in use.

You might also let me know something of the cost of getting coal delivered to this school, as it is reported that the wood supplied is not wholly suitable for heating. If a furnace were installed and coal supplied, it would solve the heating problem at this school for some years, and the Department is desirous of getting an estimate of the cost.

Your obedient servant,

September 20th, 1926.

Sir:

I have Official Letter No. 19-8-5 of the 27th ultimo, relative to the question of installing a hot air furnace in the Wikwemikong Day School, and also the cost of coal delivered at this school.

In reply I have the honour to report that after asking a dealer in this district as to the cost of a suitable furnace installed in this building with the necessary piping to the rooms in use I was advised that on account of the extensive amount of piping required the same would be approximately $350, and I might add that in addition to this it would cost $100 to put the basement under the school in shape before the furnace could be installed.

The price of coal delivered at the school in Wikwemikong would be at the present time $4.50 a ton,- Cost per ton in Owen Sound, or Soo .. $14.50
bags per ton-- 20 at 5¢ each 1.00
Freight charges 10 cents per cwt 3.60
Wharage per ton .50
Carriage from Manitowaning to Wikwemikong at the rate of 35¢ per cwt 5.00

$24.60

At present this building is equipped with good wood stoves, all in good condition, with which the building can be heated much more economically than with a coal furnace, in fact the cost will be double what it has been during the past, heated by coal.

Wood delivered in the shed at the school costs from 7¢ to 8¢ per cord, 138 cubic feet to the cord.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, September 24th, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 20th instant, giving an estimate of the cost of installing a hot air furnace in the Wikwemikong Indian Day School and also stating the cost of coal delivered at the school.

In reply I beg to say that, in view of the cost involved, the Department is not prepared to make any alterations in the present heating system at this school. It is noted that the building is equipped with wood stoves, all in good condition, with which the building can be heated more economically than with a coal furnace.

This school building is very unsatisfactory. A great many repairs are needed. A new roof should be put on at once. It is badly in need of paint. Unless repairs are made very soon the woodshed will fall down. The classrooms have not been painted in years. The teachers' quarters are very unsatisfactory.

I might suggest that the Department send an architect to look over this school building. The building has been allowed to get in a very bad state of repair. It is a question if it is advisable to spend much money on such an old building.

Note handwritten:
Make only about necessary repairs.
Ottawa, June 26, 1929.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector reports that certain repairs are badly needed at the Wikwemikong Indian Day School. He states that the roof is in poor condition, that the woodshed requires repairs and that painting is needed.

I may say that the Department hopes to arrange for a new building for this day school as soon as funds can be provided for the purpose, and only those repairs that are absolutely necessary should be considered for the next year or so. I should be pleased if you would let me have a report as to what is really necessary this year.

I received some ten days ago a letter from Rev. Fr. Artus, Missionary at Wikwemikong, in regard to the school there. He has been informed by the Agent, Mr Lewis, that the very necessary repairs on the old school would not be made because a new school was soon to be built. This is, of course, good news to him.

Now for some good news for the Department. The Ladies from Spanish are prepared to hand over free of cost the foundations intended at the time for a boarding-school for girls, but now of no use to them since the plan of the boarding-school has been abandoned. These foundations were well built of cement and are in a good state of preservation. The location is the best that can be found, on high ground, with good exposure, central, near the church. There is sufficient playground attached to the building, but if what is there is thought insufficient, Fr Artus is quite ready to add on some of the church property.

The Ladies would like that in the plans being prepared a room be reserved for an oratory, or chapel, in the teachers' quarters.

With kind regards, I am, Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, relative to the erection of a new school building at Wikomikong. The need of a new building for classroom purposes at this point has been considered by the Department. I wish to thank, through you, the Ladies of the Spanish School for their offer to hand over, free of cost, the foundations intended for the erection of a boarding school for girls, together with the site on which to erect the new day school building. I have the honour to report that during the winter months there are between fifteen and twenty pupils who remain at the school during noon hour and eat a cold lunch at Wikwemikong school.

The teachers purpose serving these pupils with a hot lunch providing that the Department will allow them $10.00 monthly to purchase supplies.

Ottawa, November 28th, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, requesting that a grant be allowed for the purpose of purchasing supplies for a midday lunch for a number of pupils of the Wikwemikong Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of an expenditure not exceeding the sum of $10 per month during the coming winter months in the purchase of the supplies required for this purpose. This lunch could be served to the pupils who remain at the school during the noon hour. It is presumed that the teachers will arrange for the preparation and serving of the lunch. If any utensils are required for the purpose, you may arrange for the purchase of same. The food supplies for the lunch should be purchased by you from time to time, and care should be taken to see that there is no waste. After the serving of this lunch has been in operation for a short time I shall be pleased to hear from you regarding the results.

You should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of the supplies, and the above authorized amount should not be exceeded each month.

The Contractor shall also be bound to furnish the Minister of Labour full information and all evidence as the Minister may deem necessary in order to satisfy him that the conditions herein contained to secure the payment of fair wages have been complied with, and that the workmen so employed as aforesaid upon the portion of the work in respect of which payment is demanded have been paid in full.

(6) In the event of default being made in payment of any money owing in respect of wages to any workman employed in the said work and if a claim therefor is filed in the office of the Minister and proof thereof satisfactory to the Minister is furnished, the said Minister may pay such claim out of the moneys at any time payable by His Majesty under said contract and the amounts so paid shall be deemed payments to the Contractor.

(7) These conditions shall extend and apply to moneys payable for the use or hire of horses or teams, and the persons entitled to payment for the use or hire of horses or teams shall have the same right to the recovery of moneys so owing them as the workmen are entitled to them in respect of wages.

(8) With a view to the avoidance of any abuses which might arise from sub-letting, it shall be understood that sub-letting, other than such as may be customary in the trades concerned, is prohibited unless the approval of the Minister is obtained; sub-contractors shall be bound in all cases to conform to the conditions set forth in the said contract, and the said Minister shall be held responsible for strict adherence to all contract conditions on the part of sub-contractor; the contract shall not, nor shall any portion thereof be transferred without the written permission of the Minister; no portion of the work to be performed shall be done at the homes of the workmen.

(9) All workmen employed upon the work comprehended in and to be executed pursuant to the said contract shall be residents of Canada, unless the Minister is of opinion that Canadian labour is not available or that other special circumstances exist which render it contrary to the public interest to enforce this provision.

September 15th, 1930.

Sir,

I am in receipt of Departmental Letter No. of the 15th of September, instant, to the effect that tenders are called for a combined day school and residence at Wikwemikong, and I have received three blue print copies of the plans and specifications for this building, and in reply I hope the honour to report that it would appear that this propose building should be quite satisfactory.

I might say that I believe that it would be more satisfactory to install a wood furnace instead of one for coal. Coal delivered in Wikwemikong will cost approximately $25.00 a ton, where wood will cost $5.00 a cord, 128 cubic feet. The whole basement should be excavated as the additional expense would be only a trifle and the extra space would answer to store a supply of firewood for winter use instead of erecting a woodshed.

On making an inspection of the old building in use as a school at present I find that there is a lot of valuable material in this structure. There would be sufficient material if taken down carefully and properly utilized to rebuild a new structure of the dimensions of the proposed new building. Of course a certain amount of new material would have to be procured such as exterior siding, windows, doors, lath, shingles, and a quantity of flooring, but I believe that all the rough material required could be taken from the old building and would entail a large expense.

If this work would commence about the middle of June next summer when the class rooms close for the holidays the building should be completed by the 1st of September.

Wikwemikong is quite remote and the cost of transportation of heavy material such as can be taken from the old building will be high.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.,

Dear Miss Burke:

I have your letter of the 24th instant, with reference to the new school and teachers' residence at Wikwemikong. The department Architect is in western Canada on duty, at the present time, and I do not wish to make any change in connection with the furnace or the size of the basement without his concurrence. The furnace will not actually be supplied for a while anyway, as there will be time to look into this carefully after Mr. Orr returns to Ottawa. The lavatory is put in new buildings, and later, when the water supply is determined, arrangements may be made for its use. The intention is to have the children use outdoor closets for the time being and the teachers could have chemical equipment in the basement.

The kitchen, of course, cannot be enlarged, as that would interfere very seriously with the whole construction. It is a nice-sized room and there is no reason why it cannot be used as a dining room as well. The draining and levelling of the site for playground purposes can be attended to next year.

Sir:

I have the honour to enclose herewith the third certificate in favour of Messrs. Jamison and McLeod, on the construction of the new Wikwemikong Day School, amounting to $1700.00.

Mr. Inspector Clark figures that the building can be completed at a cost of less than $2000.00 and recommends that the advance of $1700 now asked for be granted.

I might say for the information of the Department that I am not satisfied with the construction of basement under this building. The contractor, Mr. McLeod and Inspector Clark claim that it is in accordance with the measurement on the plan, but I differ from them. It is several feet from the floor to the beams, and in order to install the proper piping from the furnace to heat the different rooms the pipes have to circle under the beams which causes them to be very low and in the way if the basement is to be made use of for any purpose.

As we cannot agree as to the proper construction of the school building I would recommend that the Departmental Architect pay a visit to this district and settle this matter besides other little differences in connection with this building.

If possible, he should come at once while the road travelling is in good condition for later on it may be a hard trip to make.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir,

I have the honour to enclose herewith a voucher in favour of Messrs. Jamieson & McLeod amounting to $75.00 for additional excavating under the new Wikwemikong Indian Day School.

Only approximately half of the cellar under this building was to be excavated according to the specifications. In order to have ample room to store a supply of fuel for winter use and save the expense of erecting a wood shed it was necessary to have the whole cellar excavated. The contractors offered to carry out this extra work for the sum of $75.00. As they had already commenced the work and I did not have time to report this matter to the Department for approval, they should not delay the work as the winter was setting in, so I authorized them to excavate under the whole building in order to save further expense in future.

I would most respectfully recommend that this amount be paid to Messrs. Jamieson and McLeod as it was necessary to have this work carried out before the foundation was erected and it will save the expense of erecting a wood shed which would cost much more than the contractors' charge for their extra work.

June 23, 1931.

Memorandum:

On the 29th ultimo, I visited the Wigwemikong Indian Day School, which is at present conducted in the old building near the church. As far as I could learn from a brief visit, Miss Sadie Burke and Miss Agnes Manitowabi - the latter an Indian girl - are doing very efficient work.

I visited the new building which was erected during the fall and early winter, and I believe it very suitable for our purposes. There is considerable still to be done, however, before school can be conducted there, as follows:

1. Well and water supply system.
2. Sewage disposal system.
3. Outdoor toilets for boys and girls.
4. Benches for noonday lunch.
5. Cupboards for children's dishes.
6. Woodshed.
7. Kitchen cupboards and tables.
8. Dry storeroom in the cellar.
9. Cupboards and bookcases in classrooms.
10. Levelling the grounds and fencing.
11. Chemical toilets for teachers.

The ladies of the Nardene Order, who are responsible for the teaching at this school, also requested that we provide a small kiln at one end of the building as occupied; the need for this will be better determined. I believe the Department should seriously consider purchasing a few more feet at the back of the building, to take in a rather low spot there. This could
be fenced so that cattle would not get into it, and we should consider draining it. I looked at the contour of the land behind and I believe that the draining would be comparatively inexpensive. New desks are not required, as the ones now in use can be sanded and varnished and moved over.

To properly prepare the building and grounds for school purposes will require a considerable outlay and I propose to place an item in the Estimates for the coming fiscal year. Of course, there are no funds at the present time for the purpose, and, anyway, for some reason or other, the teachers are not anxious to move to their new quarters. They asked that the final work be postponed until next year. Father Artus also requested that we postpone moving to the new building until 1932. In view of the fact that funds were not available to prepare the school for occupation, I informed them that we would consider their request.

In view of the whole situation, I wish to recommend that we prepare the school for occupation early in 1932 and that the classes and teachers move over as from September first of that year.

Sir:

I have the honour to report that the Reverend G.A. Artus S.J., of Wikwemikong, has approached me with regard to the question of making use of the Wikwemikong Day School building.

This school has been closed since the summer of 1914, and the building sitting there without any use being made of it whatever. As this building has been vacated for a long period and it is difficult to watch it in order that it will not be destroyed and the Reverend Artus has promised to take good care of it if the Mission is allowed to make use of it, therefore, I would recommend that he be granted his request.

Sir:

During the last winter past a hot lunch was served at midday to the pupils attending the Wikwemikong Day School. The Department furnished the groceries and the teachers did the cooking. This practice was beneficial to the children's health besides it did encourage a satisfactory attendance. The teachers have advised me that they are willing to carry out this work again, commencing with the current month, providing the Department will supply the necessary articles to provide the lunch. As this plan worked out in such a satisfactory manner during the winter past, I would recommend that a hot lunch be provided to the pupils again this school year commencing with the current month. The cost should not exceed $10.00 a month.

There are seven more Indian Day Schools in this agency where a number of the pupils have a long distance to walk in order to allow them to attend school and have to eat a cold lunch at midday. As the cold weather is not setting in I would recommend that hot cocoa be served with their lunch at midday in each school. They agree on the opinion that there is not ample space on the first floor to accommodate two teachers, and a companion who acts as housekeeper, and they desire that the Department should arrange to have an addition to the north side of the new building in order to provide sufficient accommodation. I might say for the information of the Department that this new school is a fine structure located on one of the most suitable sites in Wikwemikong village for a school building as the location is dry, a playground can be suitably prepared with little expense, outside of cost for fencing, and the site is central to the different Indian families, and as the old school building in use at present is in a dilapidated condition, I would recommend that the new building be placed in condition for occupation as soon as possible.

Sir:

I have the honour to report that during the last two winters past, a hot lunch was served at mid-day to the pupils attending the Wikwemikong Indian Day School. The Department supplied the groceries and the teachers did the cooking. This hot lunch was beneficial to the health of the children in addition to having a tendency to encourage a more satisfactory attendance. The teachers are willing to carry out this work again commencing the first of the next month, providing the Department will supply the necessary articles to enable them to serve these lunches.

As there are a number of children in attendance at this school who are under-nourished and in need of a hot meal at mid-day I would recommend that a hot lunch be provided this school year commencing on the first of the next month. The cost of providing articles to serve this lunch should not exceed $15.00 a month.

Ottawa, October 27, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, regarding the serving of a hot lunch at midday to the pupils of the Wikwemikong Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that, as our funds for this purpose have been considerably reduced, the full amount the Department can allow for supplies for a hot lunch during the coming winter is $5.00 per month. It is considered that cocoa or tea should be served. However, you may take this matter up with the teachers and arrange for the purchase of the supplies, to an amount which must not exceed $5.00 per month. The serving of this lunch should be between November first and the end of April, 1934. Please obtain invoices itemized and in triplicate, covering the cost of the supplies. These, you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment. I regret that our funds will not permit a larger expenditure for this purpose.

Sir:

I have the honour to enclose herewith a requisition by Miss Louise Gattis for articles for use at the Wikwemikong Indian Day School.

The flag which has been in use for some years is worn out and past its usefulness. It should be replaced by a new one.

Two new pails is required for use in the kitchen as those in use are leaky and of no further use.

I have the honour to report that the school building now occupied at Wikwemikong, Manitoulin Island Unceded Reserve, is in a poor state of repair. Dear Sir:

Report on my inspection of the Manitowaning Agency on 11th - 13th ultimo.

I was requested to make enquiry regarding the delay in opening the new Wikwemikong Indian Day School erected by the Department two years ago and still unused. There has been dissatisfaction on the part of the Church officials with the location of the school as being too far from the Chapel. The old school is just across the road from the Chapel while the new one is less than half a mile distant. This undoubtedly has been an influence in keeping the teachers' from taking up residence in the new building. There are other objections, however, which until remedied prevent the school being used by pupils or teachers, namely, lack of accommodation. Toilet facilities have been provided for 60 pupils, 2 teachers and housekeeper. There is no water available so far and no cupboards or shelves in the kitchen. The grounds should be levelled and the lot fenced. If the necessary funds are not available to make these additions, I would recommend that the classrooms be opened, the teachers to remain in residence in the old building in the meantime. The Indians are anxious to have the new school opened for the pupils and it ought to be; the old building is not only unsuitable but dangerous in the event of fire or windstorm. Definite steps should be taken to have the new classrooms opened at the beginning of the September term.

(sgd) Thos McGoogin,
Inspector.

Manitowaning, September 10th, 1934.

Sir:

With reference to Departmental Letters No.19-6-5 of August the 20th and 28th last, in connection with having a well dug and erecting two toilets at the new Wikwemikong Bay School, I have the honour to report that this work is under way. Indian labour has been employed to dig the well. In order to have a sufficient supply of water it was necessary to dig to a depth of twenty feet. The Indians are busy building up the wall with dry stone and I expect that the well will be in shape to install the pump by the end of the current week.

Mr. McMullen, of Manitowaning, has been employed to erect the two toilets, and is now busy at this work, but it will now be possible to have these buildings ready for use, and the necessary shelving installed in the teachers living room before the last of October next. However the school has been re-opened in the old building and will be conducted there until the new building is ready for use.

Before the sink in the teachers living room can be made use of it will be necessary to install a drain lined with tiles in order to carry the waste water away and prevent the sewage from also washing the floor. The pipe projects only a foot or so through the concrete cellar wall, about three feet below the surface and is of no use until a drain is installed. In order to secure proper drainage it would be necessary to have the drain 100 feet in length. I would recommend that this drain be installed this fall in order that the teachers can make use of the sink during the winter months.

I would ask the Department to kindly forward an advance cheque to settle for labour which has been performed so far in digging the well and erecting foundations for the toilets, approx. $100.00.

Your Obedient Servant,

I am in receipt of Departmental Letter No. 19-6-5 of the 10th instant, with further reference to the work authorized in Official Letters of August 10th and September 17th in connection with the new Wikwemikong Indian Day School, I have the honour to report that the work authorized by the Department has been completed and the school has been removed to the new building.

A well has been dug and a pump has been placed beside the sink in the teacher's living quarters with a pipe from well so that the water can be pumped into the sink without going outside. Two new large toilets have been erected, one for the boys and one for the girls, and the sanitary toilet has been installed in the basement. Shelves have been placed in the store room in connection with the teacher's living quarters and the clock rooms have been completed and equipped with hooks for the accommodation of the pupils.

After the pump in the kitchen was installed it was found that there was not any drainage system to carry the water away from the sink. In order to have proper drainage I had to send to Owen Sound for sewer pipe to carry the refuse water from the sink across the basement floor and under the wall to a cesspool. I was forced to install.

All the work authorized by the Department has been completed, and all the classroom equipment and furniture for the teacher's living quarters have been moved to the new building, and the classroom work is conducted in the new quarters during the current week.

Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Pedley,

The industrial school at Wikwemikong has been closed and moved to Spanish River. As there are a large number of children living in the village of Wikwemikong for whom a school should be provided, the Department intends to continue the day school there, which was formerly held in the industrial school building. The Department has been in communication with Mr. Agent McLeod who states that the Rev. Father Desautels, who is acting for the church, demands a rent of $20.00 a month for the use of the building, but that the church authorities indicate that an agreement should be made between them and the Department before the Department takes possession of the building. They are either willing to rent or sell. The building needs repairs and refurnishing, as they were allowed to remove the desks to Spanish River.

After careful examination of the old records I do not see that the church has any title to the property under which they could claim rent. They have been using a certain portion of the land in the village for mission and school purposes, but as they have given up the school I consider that the building used for that purpose reverts to the band. Father Desautels claims that the school and dependents are built on land ceded by the Indians for the use of the Missionaries. I think that any concession made years ago to the missionaries was on condition that they should maintain a mission and school. As the school has been abandoned they lose any claim they ever had to the property.

The school is now closed awaiting settlement. The teacher is under salary and school material and supplies will have to be furnished before it can be opened. I think it well, as I am going to Spanish River and Sault Ste. Marie, to interview Father Desautels and find out on what he bases his claim for compensation for the use of the building. It would not be well for the Department to enter into an agreement recognizing their title to the property, as it has never been surrendered and they have simply been granted use for certain purposes. There is no doubt that the Department has a perfect right to take possession of the buildings, as it has contributed $6,000.00 as shown by the papers filed towards its acquisition and it is still in possession of the land. I consider that Father Desautels is endeavouring to obtain recognition of their claim to the land, which does not exist. The opening of the school in this building would not interfere with any valid claim the church might have for compensation, but until they can show that they have such claim there is no reason why they should be allowed to virtually close the school.

(sgd.) Martin Benson.
Ottawa, October 7, 1913.

Mr. Pedley,

I called on Mr. Agent McLeod that night and he arranged to drive me over to Wikwemikong on Sunday. We spent the day there and I am pleased to say that I arrived at a satisfactory arrangement with Father Desautels, the priest in charge, in regard to the occupancy of the old school building for the day school on the reserve. Miss Duhamel is there and ready to assume her duties as soon as this matter was settled. I may say that owing to the good offices of Father Dugas, who gave me a letter of introduction to Father Desautels, I had very little trouble in arriving at a satisfactory settlement. We are to have the use of as much of the building as we require for school purposes free of cost. As I was authorized to see that the building was made comfortable for the teacher, we took one of the large rooms and had it fitted up as a living room for Miss Duhamel and her helper. I instructed Mr. McLeod to order the number of desks required for this school from the E. H. Moyer Co., Toronto, and I saw them on my way down in reference to the shipment.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I thank you very much for your last letter. The Sisters are in the new school, I must say that I think that Mr. Lewis did his best to have the change done, but the workers were not so anxious to finish the job for their own benefits. He has been very kind to the Sisters, he comes to see if they need anything that he can give them. Little by little he will provide for the absolutely necessary.

Now there is one more problem? The old school belongs to the Department, what will become of it? If the Department never allows the Indians to use it as a club house, it will soon become an ill-famed house, where all the crimes will take place. Already they put in their tables and the same night that the Sisters left, they had organized a dance, but happily Mr. Agent firmly told the Sisters not to give the key without a written authorization from him. For the best of the reserve it should be torn down. The doors, windows, and lumber would certainly pay and over for the cost of the tearing. If it stays it will certainly be a school of corruption for the youth, as the parents have no authority on their children, girls of 13-14 roving around at midnight and over, and not few only. There

There are 48 windows, 15 doors, recreation is hard wood floor and classes etc.

Do not take the trouble to answer this letter, though it may be good to let Mr. Agent know that I think that he did his best about
about the preparation of the house. The Indians were so slow working, that it probably the cause of the delay.

The Sisters do not speak of the addition, they take courageously their cross, as coming from God, hoping so to obtain His blessings on our reserve.

The Two Fox are at home (Girls). They were to be operated for tonsils, and I did not know, so they came before the operation was performed.

The reason for asking the Department to tear down the old school is that there are so many rooms in it. You may imagine what will happen if open to the public, at night and nobody to watch for the order. As it is dangerous and of no use, it seems natural that it should disappear.

I hope that in the future I will leave you more peace, as you have not only Wikwemikong to care for.

Thanking you for your great kindness,

I remain (in union of prayers for success of yours)

Yours sincerely,

G. Bélanger, S.J.

Sir:

The question of what should be done with the building that has been used up to the present time for the Wikwemikong Day School has been brought to the Department's attention. The Department is inclined to feel that it is not necessary to keep this building standing as it will be a continual source of trouble. I have reviewed our files, and it is considered that this building really belongs to the Department, and, consequently, we have the right to demolish it.

I would appreciate your discussing the matter with the Rev. Chas. Belanger, S.J., and advising the Department if you would recommend pulling down the building. If so, you should state if the work could be done at once and what expense would be involved. Would it be possible to salvage the doors, windows and any other material that might be useful for the erection of the proposed addition to the present Wikwemikong Day School? In this event, you might let me know where the material could be stored. Please give this matter your careful consideration and report to the Department as soon as possible.

Until it has been finally decided what disposition is to be made of this building, it should be securely locked and not used for any purpose whatever.

Sir:—

With reference to Departmental Letter No. 19-6-5 of the 24th ultimo in connection with the question as to what should be done with the building that has been used up to the present time for the Wikwemikong Day School, I have the honour to report that it is my opinion that it should be left standing until at least next spring or so long as the Department would make use of the material for use in the erection of the proposed addition to the present Wikwemikong Day School. Since the old building has been vacated it has been securely locked and no use made of it whatever for any purpose, and this course of action will be continued until further instructions from the Department.

If this building were taken down under careful supervision it would be possible to salvage sufficient doors, windows, hardwood flooring of good quality, and other material that would be useful for the erection of the proposed new building, but if wrecked at present the material would tend to pile outside as there is no place for storage available at Wikwemikong for such a large amount of material, and if left outside it would become in a state of deterioration before it could be utilized for other purposes, and besides it would be possible that a large amount of the material would be carried away, so I would recommend that the Department take no action to demolish this building until next spring, at least.

Sir:

With reference to Departmental Letters No. 19-605 of August 10th and September 17th last, authorizing two toilets to be erected, and certain repairs to be made in connection with the new Wikwemikong Indian School, I have the honour to enclose herewith vouchers in my favour showing payments made for labour and material in having this work carried out, as follows:

Labour and material in connection with building of toilets and repairs to school building .... $397.43

Labour and material in connection with installing a drain and cess pool and changing sewer pipe line in basement 69.75

Labour in moving furniture, wood, desks etc from old building to new school 47.55

The toilets erected are fine large buildings with three stalls in each building and a cement trough in the one for the boys' use. Both are built of a stone foundation with cement floors and are built as near as possible as required by the school regulations of Ontario.

A large amount of repairs were required to the school building such as repairs to doors and cloak rooms, sewage pipe line, install an inside toilet, shelving in the kitchen and cellar and numerous other repairs, but during the winter months the teachers have been quite comfortable.

Dear Sir,

Your many kind words and
your confidence in reference to our
many needs.

We believe we were promised
a kitchen annex. We would be very
grateful if it could be built this
spring.

Our kitchen is 12 ft x 8 ft, and
the only room on the second floor.
It is impossible to make any
improvement that there are four
doors opening into this small room.
The necessary kitchen facilities and
store take every available place.
Vats, pans, food etc. must be kept
in the cellar making the work triple
for the housekeeper.
Visitors come at all hours and it is embarrassing to have them around at meal time. There is no privacy possible.

The kitchen door faces the north. Every time the door is opened, the wind drives the snow into the kitchen. May we please have a small porch large enough for a person to sneak by the house before entering?

I agree for more accommodation in the kitchen or we cannot move to the "front" of the bus barns.

We have never been concerned ourselves if we were permitted to have the sink at the old school installed in the cellar. The washing must be done there as the kitchen is too small. The sink could be easily connected with the sewer pipe.

We need a fence around the house but I am worried about maintenance.
and building an order to have a
safe place for the children to
enjoy their games.

There is absolutely no indication
in case a fire should occur at
night inside, there is no usual
escape for those sleeping upstairs
as the windows are too high.

Another addition is absolutely necessary
for the schoolroom.

Many pieces of glass would be saved
if the doors were removed from the old
school where but one door remains.

Nothing can be done into con-
sideration at once without
refusal to receive a unanimous
vote to the above request, which
we anticipate.

I am respectfully,

Ottawa, April 4, 1936.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the Wikwemikong Indian Day School in which she suggests that the sink at the old school be installed in the cellar of the new school and that the heavy wire screens on the cellar windows at the old school be placed over the cellar windows of the new school. Please arrange to have this work done at the earliest possible date.

You may also arrange for the purchase of a screen door and screen window for the kitchen of the new school. Another cupboard should also be built in the classroom. This work should receive your early attention, and the cost should be kept as low as possible.

The teacher would also like to have the grounds around the school cleaned and levelled, and a fence erected. Please let me have an estimate of the cost of this as soon as possible.

Yours truly,

With regard to having the grounds around the school cleaned and levelled, and a fence erected, I would report that examined the grounds, and received a quotation on suitable fence wire, gates and the necessary material for the proposed fence. The estimate cost of having the grounds cleaned and levelled with amount to at least $250.00 as there is a large amount of stone to be removed and a number of low spots to be filled which will require much labour, but when the ground is levelled and put in shape it will be an excellent playground for children as the surface is of light soil with good drainage.

In order to enclose these grounds with a fence of suitable wire, cedar posts cut from sound timber, and two gates, the approx. cost including labour would be $150.00.

You may, also, authorize the teacher to expend an amount of $10.00 in the purchase of prizes for the Christmas entertainment at this school.

Please arrange for the purchase and delivery of the sewing material required by the teacher of this school at a cost not exceeding $15.00.

The Department has been informed that the furnace is not working properly, as it does not heat some of the classrooms. We are, also, informed that wood is required for the kitchen. Please let me have a report, as soon as possible, regarding these matters, stating the approximate cost of any work that is necessary.

Yours truly,

Secretary.

Manitowaning, November 23rd, 1936.

Sir:

With regard to the last paragraph of Departmental Letter No. 19-5-5 of the 10th instant to the effect that the Department has been informed that a porch is required for the kitchen at Wikwemikong Indian School, and that the furnace is not working properly, as it does not heat one of the classrooms, I have to report that during winters past there has been a storm door on the kitchen, but the teacher would like to have a porch over the door. A suitable porch built on a new foundation with floor, one that can be removed during the warm weather and again set up in cold weather, will cost approximately $25.00.

The teacher complains that at times the furnace smokes, and is not working properly. I have examined this furnace and found that the chimney, pipe and furnace are kept clean, and seems to be in perfect working order. The only reason I can account for smoke in the classrooms is that the chimney is too low for sufficient draught. I believe if the chimney is extended two feet above it would give the furnace more draught and stop the smoke from backing up in the basement and classrooms when the wind is from the north. The chimney is a high structure and in order to add another two feet in will be costly as it will require a lot of labour and material in erecting scaffolding to reach the top for men to work in extending it higher. I consider that the cost of material and labour in having this chimney built up two feet higher will amount to $25.00 or $30.00, but I believe that it would be wise to have this work carried out as it is the only remedy to stop the furnace from smoking.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY:

Mr. Pratt requested me to go to his office today, and, when I reached there, I found Mr. Thomas Farquhar, M.P.

We discussed the proposal to demolish the old Wikwemikong school and use the material either for the new Rabbit Island school or the agricultural hall.

After some discussion, it was decided that there would be no saving effected by demolishing this building and using the material for the Rabbit Island school and, consequently, no further consideration will be given to this.

In connection with the suggestion to use the material for the agricultural hall, Mr. Farquhar expressed the opinion that this building was practically completed.

Mr. Pratt then decided that no further action should be taken at the present time towards the demolition of this building.

I expressed the opinion that it should be demolished in the near future. Mr. Pratt agreed with this and stated that the matter could be taken up again as soon as a new agent is appointed.

In view of the decision made at this meeting, I wrote Mr. Lewis under cover of a letter dated today.

[Signature]

Memorandum

The Director,
Surveys & Engineering Branch.

Re: Old school building at Wikwemikong, Ont.

I understand that one of your engineers is being sent to supervise the construction of the new school at Rabbit Island.

This school is approximately five miles from the Indian village of Wikwemikong, at which place there is an old building which was formerly used for both residential and day school purposes.

This building was erected approximately 25 years ago but has not been used for the past four or five years. I am inclined to feel that this building should be demolished and I would appreciate it if you would instruct your engineer to inspect it.

I would like to know the condition of the lumber and other material in the building, the approximate cost of demolishing it and any other information that he can obtain which will assist us in deciding what disposition might be made of the lumber and material in the building.

Director.

EXTRACT from letter dated July 5th, 1938, from Engineer R.R. Ross, Engineering & Construction Service.

"As instructed I have inspected the old building at Wikwemikong which was formerly used for both residential and day school purposes. According to local information, this building was erected approximately 60 years ago and has not been in use since a number of years.

"The building is two story, 50 feet by 100 feet, of frame construction on a stone foundation. The joists under the floors are 2" x 10" and 2" x 8" over the second floor ceiling, 15' and 14 feet long, spaced 16" on centres. The rafters are 2" x 6" and the studs 2" x 6" and the inside and outside sheathing is rough one inch boards. The exterior walls and ceilings are lathed and plastered and the interior walls are finished in a tongue and groove V joint.

"All the lumber appears to be white pine and in a fairly sound condition, with the exception of most of the exterior woodwork which has rotted in places. The windows are large and of little value, each containing six lights, 8 by 10 inches, of an inferior quality of glass. The only flooring of any value is in a portion of the building that has been refloored with maple. It is understood the local Indians are requesting this hardwood flooring for use in an Agricultural Hall which they are now constructing.

"The roof has commenced to leak badly and the building will further deteriorate rapidly since mudstall filling has been used in the interior, evidently for sound deadening.

"The cost of demolishing the building would depend largely upon the care with which the materials are salvaged. However, it is estimated that to salvage most of the sound lumber and to clean up the premises would cost approximately $400.00."

Sir,

With reference to Departmental Letter No. 19-5 of the 21st of June, I have the honour to report that on making an inspection of this building recently I find that the roof has been leaking again. Since this school has been built there has been a great deal of trouble with the roof, and especially in the winter months as ice forms and when the weather becomes mild the moisture soaks through around the dormer windows. The roof over each dormer window is too flat, and there does not seem to be any flashing in the meeting of the two roof-slopes which is necessary. In order to have a dry roof it will be necessary to have all the dormer windows re-shingled with galvanized iron flashing placed in all the valleys around the dormers, and in order to have this work carried out it will be quite expensive and a large amount of the shingles will have to be replaced by new material. I estimate that it will be necessary to this roof will cost at least $100.

Miss Trudeau's class-room is also leaking. In order to safeguard against any further damage the plaster will have to be removed and the walls repainted.

We placed pails on the floor to catch at least some of the water so that it might not lodge on the floor during the holidays and destroy it. The rain comes freely through all the upstairs windows.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle,

RE - Old Building, Wikwemikong,
Ontario.

With reference to your memorandum of the 27th ultimo, the following is an extract from a report submitted by Engineer Ross on the matter in question.

"It is estimated that the materials which could be salvaged from the above building for $400.00 would be worth approximately $600.00."

"As it would probably be difficult to find a market in this locality for such a large quantity of salvaged building material, I do not consider the expense required justified. I would, however, recommend that the building be sold for wrecking."

It is considered that there are two possibilities of disposing of this building:

First: In view of the Engineer's report, tenders might be received from local firms for the complete removal of the building and salvage material. It is quite probable that the method would net the department more than $200.00 which it is estimated would be saved through the demolition of the building by day labour.

Second: The Indian Affairs Department might possibly consider that the Indians on the reserve could utilise the salvaged material to an equal if not greater advantage than the estimated cash value of $600.00. On this basis, arrangements might be made by the Indian Agent to have the building demolished by Indian labour in return for the salvaged materials.

Respectfully submitted,

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,

November 14, 1938.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I am very thankful for the kind information received from you regarding requisition, sewing material etc.

Since then the roof has been repaired, but to date no doors, but when Mr. McCookin came he told Mr. Lewis to get them so they may be forthcoming. Nor has anything been done toward pumping the water upstairs.

The serious question of heating the classrooms still confronts us. I had a furnace-fitter who was installing a new furnace in the rectory, come to see what was the matter with the one here. He said that it was by no means large enough to heat the building. That there was a large number of pipes that were too small and the length of several of them (some over two or five feet) were altogether out of order. He said that anyone who understood anything about a furnace would not pretend to say it would heat a building like this, and that it would be condemned by any furnace fitter, not that there was anything much the matter with it put on account of the way it was piped etc.

Mr. McCookin was here before I had this information, but I told him that we were most uncomfortable in the class rooms, despite the fact that we kept all upstairs pipes turned off so as to have the heat for them. Only one of the two hot air pipes in the house room functions properly. I told the furnace fitter this pipe was examined, but, according to the furnace fitter, the too long stretch of pipes etc., they could not function properly nor could it be remedied. The same furnace, he said if placed in a different place, would be believed to heat half the building.

The parents have been, and are complaining, that the children are cold and it is with good reason. Poor tots are so poorly clad it adds to their misery.

I have a suggestion, yes, more... a request... that a chimney be built at the front end of the building (it could be built outside and braced to the roof) and that a cooking range be placed in the senior room. The furnace pipes of senior room could be turned to junior room and in this way perhaps heat it properly.

Besides heating the senior room, I could very conveniently take the cooking lesson right there. The children could make their soup during the winter months as well. This too would fall in with Mr. Healy's desires of household science. I would be delighted to have this convenience for the cooking class, as well as to have a comfortable class room.

With hopes to receive your kind assistance in this difficulty.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

WIKWEIKONG SCHOOL

Sir:

I wish to report, the teacher of Wikwemikong School, has asked to have a porch 10 ft. by 12 ft. built at the back kitchen door, which would serve as a shelter from winter storms, as their quarters are very cold in winter. They also need the space for storing a little wood, washing and possibly an oil stove in the summer time.

It could be built inexpensive, with sheeting and paper on roof, studding and V-Joint siding, with one door and one window. It can be built and painted by Indian labour for about $50.00 for material and labour. There should also be provided about 20 ft. of eaves troughing to catch rain water, which would cost about $3.00.

The two outside doors at main entrance to classrooms are so badly checked that snow in large quantities blows in and is damaging the floors. I have consulted some local contractors and find the doors cannot successfully be repaired without considerable expense; in fact it would be impossible to get a decent job done here and I would recommend the purchase of two new doors 7' X 3' X 4" white pine, can be procured locally for $2.50 each delivered. It would be advisable also to install new locks, as the old ones are in very bad shape. I would recommend a double grip combination lock with night latch, which costs $12.00 or with one grip and one knob $10.00. An ordinary front door set with knobs would cost $6.00, labour to hang $4.00.

Yours very truly,

Sir:

I wish to make a report on the school building at Wikwemikong. The building was evidently intended to have pillars in the class rooms, which was substituted with stub posts under the beams, with heavy rods crossing underneath to support the ceiling. Through time the upper floors have settled away from the walls and partitions leaving openings nearly two inches wide, through which the wind comes in, making the place very hard to heat. I would recommend placing about a three inch moulded base board over the other base-board in the rooms upstairs, to close the openings.

It will require about 100 lineal feet of 3¢ moulded base, which will cost about .03¢ per foot delivered. Possibly .50¢ for nails and should be painted I suppose, although that is not so important at the moment. I think a carpenter would quote it for about .50¢ and about $2.00 for material and labour to rent it.

The teacher at Wikwemikong School has also requested to have three benches made for use of the children taking hot lunch. I can have these made for about three dollars for material and labour.

The school organ also needs some little repairs, which will cost about $2.00. I would recommend these expenditures be authorized.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter File No.16-9-5 dated May 23rd; in regard to repairs etc., for the various Day Schools in the Agency, I wish to advise that with the amount of money available, two schools is all we could attempt to paint on the outside. I would say Puzwah and Kaboni are in the worst need of it, about $175.00 each.

West Bay School needs renovating, repairing plaster and painting on the inside of both class room and living quarters, which will require about $120.00. Birch Island needs renovating and painting inside class room about $75.00.

Sucker Creek and Rabbit Island Schools need some gravel hauled to cover the clay around entrances and the floors need shellac and varnishing and a little paint on the entrance platforms, steps and guard rails. This will require about $25.00 each.

At the present time, I do not know of anything urgently required at Gheshegwaning School.

I believe it has been customary in the past at some of the schools at least, to give the school one thorough cleaning each year in addition to the usual cleaning by the Janitor.

The salaries of the Janitors are very small, and I think, were based on the assumption that such things would be paid for extra, although I am of the opinion it would be preferable to pay the Janitor sufficient to take care of all the cleaning, putting on storm windows, etc.

Yours very truly,

July 6, 1942

Sir:

Certain amounts were included in the 1942-43 estimates for this agency to repair, renovate and paint various schools.

Wikwemikong and Birch Island Schools are in the worst need of painting outside. Although an amount was included in the estimates for West Bay School, with the exception of the roof, the outside painting could be left for another year.

The inside of the Kaboni and Shuswap Schools are in the worst need of attention, but I am enclosing herewith a requisition to cover both inside and outside of Wikwemikong School if funds are available.

There is a very large roof on Wikwemikong School, and it is a little more economical to purchase the stain by the barrel. One barrel should be about sufficient for Wikwemikong and West Bay School. You will note I have selected a creosote stain for these buildings, which is much cheaper than that used on the agency office and residence last year.

I have quoted prices obtained from the local hardware merchant, C. W. Hinds, which are just ten per cent above wholesale prices to cover cost of freight, cartage etc.

For convenience, I would recommend that the supplies be purchased locally, as quite frequently a little more or less of certain colors of paint are required.

I expect to be able to secure Indian labour at thirty to thirty-five cents per hour, and the cost of labour for all work at Wikwemikong School, renovating, painting, laying linoleum on kitchen floor, installing new blackboards, overhauling and cleaning furnace and pipes is estimated at $190.00.

If the funds are available, please forward an advance cheque for this amount, to pay wages, when purchase of material is authorized.

Yours very truly,

In view of the estimates for this Agency arriving late last year, and in view of subsequent correspondence, I assume there will be very little, if any money available for repairs etc. to schools this year.

Indian Affairs Branch,

Ottawa, Canada.

The teachers at Wikwemikong School have complained more or less ever since I have been Agent here, of the furnace smoking occasionally, and we have attempted in various ways to remedy the difficulty without success.

The cause I believe, is due to the location, the school being at the foot of a high hill, and although there is quite a high chimney, there seems to be poor draught, particularly when the wind is from the direction of the hill.

I had an extension and cap put on the chimney this fall, but Miss Gattie claimed this was more of a detriment, and had it removed almost immediately.

Miss Gattie has recommended and asked for a chimney baffle with 10" rotary head ventilator similar to that used at Manitowaning Residential School at a cost of $35.00. There will also be an additional cost for having this installed, and I would recommend its purchase, as something must be done to prevent the smoking.

I also wish to report the 25 gallons of stain was sufficient to cover the large roof on Wikwemikong School. I was told by the travelling salesman that this colour may not be available next year, so have had Mr. Hinds order twenty gallons more which can be applied next year. It was too late in the season to start the work when the stain arrived last fall.

EXTRACT FROM W.J. GREENING'S REPORT,
on the above school, dated May 20th, 1946.

"I believe that this teacher is doing as well as could be expected. She is interested and devoted, and tries in every way to help her young pupils.

Young Indian children, however, with their imperfect knowledge of English, present their own problems, and, as remarked previously, fifty-four such children are too many for any teacher to handle with any degree of satisfactory results.

I wish to report some repairs are required at the two room school in Wikwemikong Village.

Ottawa, July 11th, 1947.

Mr. Chas. R. Johnston, Indian Agent,
Manitowaning, Ontario.

Re: Wikwemikong Indian Day School

The Hardine Sisters have given up teaching services at the Wikwemikong School and consequently Miss Louise Cattie will not return after the summer holidays.

We are endeavouring to complete arrangements to have the Sisters of St. Joseph take charge of this school. I understand you recently discussed the situation there with Inspector Arnell and Rev. Father Drouin. The school and two rented annexes were surveyed by Mr. Clark of this Department (on Sunday, June 29th) and representatives of the Sisters of St. Joseph.

It will be necessary for us to improve the accommodation for the sisters as they intend to send three teaching sisters and a housekeeper.

Following Mr. Clark's return to Ottawa, Departmental officials have carefully considered the whole matter and we would like you to give immediate attention to the following:

(1) Repairs to Furnace in the School - You should have a competent furnace man look at the heating plant and supply a detailed estimate of the repairs that are required to make the furnace operate satisfactorily. Mr. Clark is of the opinion that the chimney and pipes should be cleaned and that the seams on the fire box and hot air compartment should be cemented. It is also possible that new grates are needed and that the hot air delivery ducts should be insulated.
(2) Extend the Lean-to at the rear of the School. In this connection Mr. Clark discussed the situation with the sisters and I enclose a rough plan showing two additions which can be placed on the building. If these were erected they would give considerable additional accommodation. The present lean-to at the rear of the building was built by John King in September, 1939. You will note from the plan it is proposed to extend this addition both ways from the existing lean-to. Please obtain an estimate on carrying out this work and if necessary additional windows can be placed in the additions.

(3) The Installation of Electric Plant. We are favourably disposed to installing a small electric plant and available types are being considered. In this connection please obtain from Father Dwyer and forward a description in technical terms and the price of the motor which he told Mr. Clark was available.

(4) Septic Tank. The plans and files that we have on hand do not indicate whether a septic tank or cesspool exists. Please ascertain if either was supplied at any time. If there is such an installation, you should let me know the cost of putting it in proper operation. However, if neither a cesspool or a septic tank has been installed, you should let me know what expenditure would be involved in providing it.

(5) Please obtain and forward a detailed estimate of piping necessary in the building and securing a supply of hot and cold water. This is on the understanding that electricity for operating the pump (but not for heating the water) will be available.

We would appreciate it very much if you would give this matter your immediate attention and let us have a complete report at the earliest possible date.
During the course of Mr. Clark's conversation with Father Dwyer, the latter stated that the Jesuit Order would be prepared to consider selling the large stone building which they at present own. We are not prepared to consider this offer at the present time but within the next few months we will have one of the officials of the Surveys & Engineering Branch examine the building with a view to ascertaining what expenditure would be involved in placing it in proper condition to be used for classroom purposes and in providing living accommodation. We have had experience in renovating such buildings in other places and usually a large expenditure is necessary.

If the official who visits Wikwemikong decides that we can renovate this building at a reasonable cost, we will provide the funds in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1948-49.

The renovations mentioned in the first part of this letter are only intended to be temporary and if carried out reasonably soon, will provide fairly comfortable living quarters for the sisters for the academic year 1947-48.

Bernard Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Re: Wikwemikong Day School.

It is intended to supply an Electric Lighting Plant for the Wikwemikong Day School. The plant will be used to light the whole building and to operate the pump for the water system.

It is suggested that the most satisfactory type of equipment will be an Automatic Plant delivering a voltage of 110 A.C.

The building is already wired but lacks electric fixtures. A full set of plumbing was installed but there is no Septic Tank or Water Cistern. These are also to be installed along with the Electric Plant preferably before school opens in September.

The plan for the school is No. 625, dated June, 1938. The building has been modified since that date. It now has a full basement and a lean-to at the rear, the dimensions of which are 12' x 10'. This lean-to is being extended to give an additional floor area of 300 square feet.

Mr. Coll Johnston, Dept. of Indian Agency,
Manitowaning, Ontario.

From his recent visit to several schools in your Agency, Mr. Doucet reports the following:

1. Wawaikong Indian Day School - The school plumbing is leaking between the two floors above the kitchen. The Agent has been authorized to have this checked immediately and the necessary repairs made. The school roof leaks at two places. The Agent has been authorized to have this thoroughly inspected and have the spots where the leakage occurs re-shingled. This may entail a few shingles or a couple of square feet. However, as it is ruining the ceiling on walls, it was necessary to have this done immediately. Ceilings at the spot of leakage will have to be re-plastered. It is not more than a few square feet at each spot.

There is plenty of water in the well but apparently the cylinder of the pump is leaking and would need new leathers. The Agent has been asked to have this done. It should entail very little expense.

The Department confirms the decisions made by Mr. Doucet and wish you to have the above done as soon as possible.

We have received your wire re the condenser and coil for the electrical plant. These articles have been ordered through Fairbanks-Morse and will be forwarded to you as soon as they arrive.

2. West Bay Indian Day School. - A great deal of the cold air enters the kitchen from the foundation. This should be thoroughly banked with the surrounding fill in the fall and in the spring cleared away to prevent the lumber from decaying. Prices should be obtained immediately from an insulation company on insulating the school and residence.

I enclose herewith a requisition for supplies for Wikwemikong Indian Day School comprising three class rooms. Quotations have been obtained from C.W. Hinds and S.W. McPhee of Manitowaning and a few items from Eaton's Catalogue.

I would suggest the purchasing agent secure the Sewing Machine, Looms, Softball bats and volley ball. The Looms are quoted from Moyer's Arts and Crafts Catalogue Page 62.

In connection with the generating plant furnished for this school, I beg to advise the plant is still not in operation. Mr. George H. Hamilton, Electrician, who set the plant up has been endeavoring for some time to get another magneto from the Company. He did manage to get it to operate for a short time by manual control and then the oil pump assembly had to be returned to the Company. This was considered to be defective and was being replaced free of charge but was not the proper parts and had to be returned again on December 20, 1948.

I would be pleased if the Department can do anything to expedite shipment of repairs for this machine.

C. R. Johnston,
Superintendent,

In connection with the generating plant purchased for Wikwemikong School, we have now received the proper oil pump assembly and Mr. Morrison has been able to try the machine out with the new magneto.

As you know he had it working for a time on batteries (Manual Control) until the oil pump broke, while waiting for another magneto. It will still not operate on the magneto but appears to work quite satisfactorily on batteries.

The Sisters at the School would, I believe, be very glad to have it even as it is (Manual Control,) however, in telephone conversation with Mr. Doucet, he advised me to have the machine returned if it did not give satisfaction, however, before returning the machine would it be possible that the Company would send their own mechanic to examine it?

I would suggest we should not keep the machine unless it will operate automatically, that is, by remote control. Operating on the batteries, it is necessary for someone to go to the building each time to start and stop it.

C.R. Johnston,
Superintendent,

The Secretary:

Mr Inspector White in his report on the Wikwemikongising school states that the quarters provided for the teacher are too small and in many respects quite unsuitable and if some better accommodation is not provided, it is doubtful if the teacher can remain.

Mr Agent Sims called attention to the lack of accommodation last year and he was asked to submit the question of its provision to the Band.

Sir:

With regard to the old teacher's residence in connection with the Wikwemikonging Day School, which has not been in use during the last twelve years past, I have the honour to report that this building is in a very bad state of repair, and is past being any further use as a residence.

It is unlikely that the school at this point will reopen again, and it should be the case that the school would reopen a new teacher's residence will have to be erected as the old building is falling down.

This building is an old log structure which has been some years ago remodelled and fixed up to accommodate the teacher and if taken down some fairly good building material could be gotten out of it and Joseph Mamagos and Mrs. Antoine Wabanoose who had their dwellings destroyed by fire during the past winter have offered me $300 for the building.

As this building is of no further use as a teacher's residence, and of very little value, I would most respectfully recommend that I be given authority to make a sale of it, at a price not less than $100.

Your obedient servant,

Right Reverend Sir,

I have to call your attention to the very unsatisfactory attendance at the Whitefish River school. The return for the quarter ended September, last, shows an enrolment of only two pupils, with an average, to quote the teacher's remarks, of "Reductio ad absurdum". They only attended six days out of the whole quarter, although the teacher was present every day.

The average attendance for the year ended June 30, last, was only three, and for the past five years the average has never exceeded four. Your Lordship will see that the Department can hardly be expected to maintain a school which shows such poor results as the Whitefish River, and it thinks that an effort might be made to have the few children on the reserve placed in the Shingwauk Home, where there are vacancies, as it will be impossible to continue the school much longer.

The Department would like to have Your Lordship's views on this matter.

I have the honour to be,
Right Reverend Sir,
Your obedient Servant,
