My Dear Lord Bishop,

Replying to yours of the 2nd inst., I have the honour to communicate from the Department of Indian Affairs having reference to the unsatisfactory condition of things in connection with the school at Shuswap Lake. I have to say that my experience for the present, and most of the coming weeks are such that I shall be unable to get to the North Shore in time but if the weather shows an inclination to help me, I will try to get on and make thorough inquiry into matters. But should it become evident that I may not be able to get there till after the Lakes are frozen sufficient to admit of travel by them, I am only aware in a general way, in the present situation, that the Department is correct in its statement, and also agree that it would appear better to have the few children sent to the women. In any case, the Church can do no less than a mission and can do nothing in that direction whether the Indians can be induced to take the views of it or not.

I am anxious to know what the Indians who do not attend are doing that should be sent to the women. I do not think the cause of the non-attendance lies with the teacher. Mr. Ross has been very satisfactory to all parties, and we have often answered his complaints but our knowledge was insufficient in order to come to better results. We do not think there are more than six children of school age on the Reserve, that we could call permanent, perhaps not that number, and it would appear that these have been about almost all summer. It is a habit with these Indians to go off to the "few hills mines" to obtain work, taking their families with them where they get literally paid pay, but they do not work steady and as a rule a part deal of what they earn is used to purchase whisky. And I fear the minds of the women do not improve by their
Coming into contact with unscrupulous whites, they are seduced beyond all control and are put in touch with anything such as alcohol or sickness for a long period of time. In winter the men go to the lumber camps where wages are paid but they do not work. They are paid and permitted to spend their earnings in liquor. In many cases the women accompany them and are provided with a hut to live in upon condition that they agree to work for the man belonging to the camp. And of course the children have to go too. At such places shelter is often given to women friends or relations of the Indians and their wives and their residence there is often fear is not for the best purpose. When Indians living in the number of persons belonging to Birch Island, i.e., Whitefish River there are quite a number owing to the Board of School age, yet they do not reside there and I should judge surely that their health would suffer, but are paid at whatever place they present themselves to the Agent. If these Indians with their families were compelled to reside within the Reserve and instructed the land to come to participate in the annuities or benefits of the Board I feel certain that there would be a marked improvement in the number at school and also in the general welfare of the Indians as a whole. I expect to hear to say that drunkenness among the Indians is increasing at such a rate that a sober man is almost rare, and this situation is only to be borne until the law is applied, the restriction of liquor to the Indians is carried out.

I have to report that on Friday the 28th ultimo while over at the matter then points, I called a meeting of the Indians to consider the matter of the closing of the school by the Department owing to the meager attendance of pupils at the White Fish River School. There was a fairly number present and all appeared pretty interested in the matter. Nothing and all the leading people were present opposed to the school being closed. They all agree that the attendance has been small they state that the number of children of school age resident on the reserve is approximately 100 would appear that there were only two - this quarter apparently the school will only open until June or the 30th. The Indians say that they will do all that is possible to put better at dinner. It is evident that a "pull" exists between the Indians in the own residents in between those that reside in the reserve and their resident at the mouth of the White Fish River. Where there are a number of children of school age. It appears that they have wanted the school there. But as they hear my signature to the land and are outside the reserve limits I feel that it would be wrong to ask for the change. Sir,

I have the honor to report that His Lordship the Bishop of Algoma has expressed his wish to have the school at Whitefish River re-opened. When I was at the reserve in July I took a careful census of the resident children thereof school age and who if the school were re-opened would be expected to attend.

I found that at that time there were five children between the ages of six and fifteen years resident on the reserve. Since my visit I understand that three of these have been admitted to the Shingwauk home which would leave only two of school age there. There are also two children that are in their fifth years and who might attend if the school were re-opened. The Bishop also suggested that the teacher be allowed to teach for six months on the reserve and for six months at the mouth of the Whitefish River where there are several Indian families residing. I do not view this proposition favorably as I do not think the Indians at Whitefish River mouth should be encouraged in any way to remain there as they have no rights, but, are simply squatters on surrendered land. There are seven or eight families living at this point who are members of Sucker Creek, Spanish River, South Bay and other bands and there might be half a dozen Indian children of school age there. There is no school house accommodation and I do not consider it would be practical at all to establish a school at this point.

With reference to the communication from His Lordship the Bishop of Alberta regarding the building of schoolhouse and church building at Birn Island on the Whitefish River Indian reserve, I beg to say that this building was erected in 1869, under the supervision of the Rev. Dear Mr Scott,

When on the Indian Village at the mouth of Whitefish River last week, the Indians, living in the surrendered portion of the Whitefish River Reserve, asked to have a day school opened in their Village. There are 20 Indian children of school age, besides 9 white children, in all 30 children with no provision made for their schooling. The range where all the Indians reside is less than one square of a mile in extent. All the Indians are in three families of which are Protestants excepting one Indian family, French, who are nearly all the Indians being of the Shagor and Creeks. There never was a school at this village, but there is a building at Whitefish River about 7 miles south, that is now used for Anglican church, the school having been closed for some years. The house of John Kishkoperais (marked X on the enclosed sketch), which is now used for services on Sunday, can be rented in town for a year, for the use of the school. Dear Mr. Bowman:

I have your letter of the 8th instant, with further reference to the case of Mr. J. Hardeman, who taught in Indian schools for many years and who is now teaching at Whitefish Falls. Allowance cannot be given in his case, as teachers of Indian day schools do not contribute to any superannuation fund.

Teachers of Indian day schools are nominated, in the great majority of cases, by the churches interested in the work and the Department of Indian Affairs does not feel largely responsible for these matters upon their retirement. Dear Sir:

On my return to the Sault I have found your letter of April 26th regarding the Whitefish Falls combined school and have made some enquiries. Our missionary in charge and his wife, Mrs. Stump, are of the opinion that the attendance in the fall at this school will probably be increased by at least ten Indian children. During the past year they report that the attendance has been bad for several reasons.

The reasons which they refer to are as follows:

1. There has been a great lack of work and this has caused the parents to move about from place to place taking their children with them.
2. Several of the children have reached the age of thirteen or fourteen and have stayed away from school because they feel too old. There is no truant officer and I am told that the Indian agent never visits the school.
3. Many children have been kept at home owing to lack of clothing.
4. In a year's time it is expected that a number of small children at home will be of school age.

I gather that under normal conditions the school attendance should within another year be considerably improved.

I do sincerely hope that the Department is not going to let us down after having encouraged us to spend a very large amount of money on building a really good school where the white and Indian children can be taught together. It was definitely stated at the time that the Department would increase its grant in order that there might be a surplus each year in order to help pay for the school in time. Surely the Department is not going to let us down after less than a year. I notice that in your letter of August 30th last you definitely say that, "In the event of the Anglican Church authorities..."
erecting a two-room school making adequate provision in this building for both the Treaty Indian children and the half-breeds, the Department will increase its allowance of $600 to $1000 a year.

May I venture to add that I hope you will not pay too much attention to what the Indian Agent says on this matter because I had occasion a few months ago to report him to the Department in connection with slackness in another Indian mission on Manitoulin Island, and it is probable that he does not feel well disposed towards us on that account, although a reference to my letter will show that I delayed taking action until I could no longer avoid it.

I will make further enquiries with a view to sending you the names and ages of all the Indian and half-breed children in the mission and will communicate with you again when I receive a reply.

Ottawa, May 12, 1930.

Right Reverend Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the 11th instant and to thank you for the information contained therein.

I may state that I was somewhat disturbed when I learned from the agent's report that there were comparatively few Indian pupils in attendance at the Whitefish Falls School.

For a number of years the Dominion Government followed a somewhat liberal policy with respect to the education of half-breed children. In view of the fact, however, that the Indian pupil population of Canada is now increasing at the rate of approximately 300 per annum, the Government has been compelled to review the claims of half-breed children. A letter, approved by the Minister, and dated Ottawa, December 10, 1937, was sent out to inspectors, Indian agents and principals of Indian schools. I am enclosing herewith a copy of this letter for Your Lordship's information. It is scarcely necessary to state that there are still in the Dominion a number of districts in which provision has not yet been made for the education of Indian children.

It is just possible that a misunderstanding exists with respect to the construction of the school at Whitefish Falls. I was not aware at any time that the Department encouraged the church authorities to proceed with the erection of a school at that point. We did, however, very definitely promise an increased grant if such a school were constructed, on the understanding that approximately 23 children for whom education the Department was responsible would be enrolled at the institution.

Halfbreed children are, of course, definitely the responsibility of the provincial government. This applies also to enfranchised Indians. Unless there is a steady increase in the number of Indian pupils at the Whitefish Falls School, it is altogether likely that our right to pay the present grant will be challenged by the auditors. I feel confident that a little cooperation between the teachers and the Missionary in charge and the Indian agent for the district would result in a substantial increase in the attendance.

Dear Mr. Hives:

You may probably remember an interview you had with me when I first entered the Department a little over three years ago. We discussed at that time the desirability of establishing a school for the education of a number of Indian children who were without educational facilities and who resided at Whitefish Falls, Ontario. The Department agreed at that time that if the Indian population justified it we would be prepared to contribute $1,000 toward the salary of a teacher at that school.

However, we find ourselves unable at this time to justify such a grant, or indeed any grant, in view of the reports that have come in to us from the Indian agent. In a letter dated February 29, 1940, the Indian agent writes:

"I wish to report that there is only one legitimate Indian child attending the Whitefish River Combined School at the present time.

"There are however 51 white and half-breed children enrolled, 14 of whom are half-breeds, 4 of whom are illegitimate children whose mothers have later married white men and lost their Indian status. There are 7 Protestant Indian children on the Whitefish River reserve who are not attending any school at the present time, being anywhere from 3 to 7 miles distant from the Whitefish River school."

An attempt will be made to pay the grant promised in full for the academic year 1939-40, but no grant can be made immediately following that date. I am writing a confidential letter to you at this time, remembering the interest you took in the establishment of this school. I personally find it exceedingly difficult to understand why the education of these white and half-breed children has not been assumed by the provincial authorities. I feel confident that if the plight of these children was brought to the attention of the Ontario Minister of Education he would immediately make provision for their education.

In any event, you can readily appreciate that it is impossible to take funds voted by Parliament for the education of Indian children and use such funds for the education of either white or half-breed children. I am enclosing herewith copy of a letter relating to the education of half-breed children, sent out by the Department in December, 1937.

After my interview with Mr Jackson, which I feel was very satisfactory, for he informed me the whole matter would be reconsidered, and in view of facts regarding our forty years work in White Fish Falls, and also the fact that we are looking after the education of the Indian children of that place, even though the attendance of legitimate Indian children is at present so low, etc., it is bound to rise, and in fact, there are prospects of an increase in the near future. In view of this, Mr Jackson said he would go into the matter with you again, and gave me some hope of a grant, perhaps half of what you have been giving, for the education of Indian children at our school at Whitefish Falls.

After leaving him, I decided to go to Toronto, and interview the Department of Education there. I made an appointment with Mr McArthur who received me very kindly, and listened very sympathetically. The Deputy Minister of Education said he could not give me anything official, but informed me of his willingness to recommend an increase of $500.00 to the grant his department have given. He asked me to inform you of this with the hope that your department would continue your interest and support in connection with the Whitefish Falls School. The people at that place are quite unable to support the school, as they are made up of Tourist guides, who get work just during the tourist season, and are mostly on relief during the Winter.

Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter dated July 31st, 1942, File 19-10-1 enclosing a list of children attending Whitefish Falls School, who are alleged to be Indians.

The children are all recognized Indians except Julian, Lionel and James Keshikgobness. Julian is the illegitimate son of Annie Keshikgobness "deceased" formerly paid under number 46 Whitefish River Band, but was never entered on the Band Membership.

Lionel is said to be an illegitimate child of Susan Keshikgobness No. 49 Whitefish River Band, but was never taken on the band membership, as it was the practice at that time to exclude illegitimate children.

Susan later married a white man, and as near as I can determine, James is a child of this marriage, although Susan is now deserted by her husband.

Several of these children did not attend regular last winter and spring for various reasons as you would see by the school report. Some were just beginners, and live a long distance from school, and others had whooping cough, while some of it is just negligence on the part of the parents.

She was advised that the records in this office did show that there had not been any returns received for the above periods, and therefore the grants would not be paid to the Diocese, but if she would prepare returns for the above quarters and forward to this office they would be submitted to the Department for consideration of the grants long past due being paid to the Diocese, but that it might not be possible for the Department to make payments as payments of grants so long standing is against the regulations.

Dear Sir,

I have been informed today that Chief Shabnimiki has sent in a request for seats etc., for the White Fish Lake School. I state that in my opinion and that of some others of the Band, it is an unnecessary expense. The seats now in use are made of wood and strong and in every way suitable for the school. Consider that there are other articles which we stand in more need than these seats. Farming implements for instance. The Chief did not consult me in this matter nor any of the councillors. I therefore beg strongly to object to such unnecessary wasting of our funds.

Yours sincerely,

Jas. Robitaille,
second Chief.
I have the honor to report that Chief Waheminiak of the White Fish Lake Band has applied for 20 new seats and desks and one Teachers Desk for the School House at White Fish Lake. The desks asked for are such as are supplied by Messrs A McMillan and Son of Chatsworth Ont., and cost $3.50 for seat and desk and $7.00 for teachers desks. The number is more than is required for strictly school purposes, but as the school house is used for church purposes and also as a council room the quantity applied for is not too great.

I enclose a communication from the second chief who objects to the expenditure being incurred.

I respectfully recommend that the Indians should be instructed to hold a council and decide the matter of the seats and desks by a vote.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

My dear Sir,

In my recent visit to the Indians who manifested great interest in the school, I found that they were very anxious to have their children educated. They are very intelligent and the chief has proposed that they should have a school house and a teacher. The two places are very near together and the people are few. Consequently, they choose they might all live at Kettle Island. But the fact remains that 6 families have gone to Kettle Point, and are living there; and since so children belong to that little settlement, it seems, from all accounts, that school. As it is they are having no school facilities.

I would bring the case before the Department and ask what view they take of this case. Will they dispense to build a school for these people and give them necessary work? And will they arrange for the teacher at Kettle Island dividing his time in some way if he is willing between the two schools?

I again request you to urge that the teacher at Kettle Island, Mr. S. Harris, whose work is trying in those present circumstances, should receive $200 per annum instead of $300.

Yours faithfully,

My dear Mr. Scott:

Ever since I became Bishop of the Diocese of Algoma, twenty-six years ago, we have had the use of a small building at Birch Island, part of the Whitefish Indian Reserve. The Indians at that point are divided between the Church of England and the Roman Catholic Communion. There is a disposition at the present time to claim the building for use by the band as a council chamber. This is not at all satisfactory to us, as it interferes with our use of it for religious purposes. Will you kindly tell me the history of this building, and what rights the Church of England has in it. One of the oldest residents declares that the materials were provided by the Church, and that it is to the best of his knowledge and belief a church building. Of course, if it is a Government building the Department has a right to determine what its uses shall be; nevertheless, after so long a period of use, some clear and generous rights should belong to the Church of England, her use of it having been unbroken through the period referred to. Will you kindly let me have an answer at your earliest convenience.

Believe me,

Very faithfully yours,

George Algoma.

Sir:

I am in receipt of Official Letter of the 4th instant, in regard to the report made to the Department by His Grace the Archbishop of Algoma in reference to the building at Birch Island which for some years past was used as a combined church and school, and in reply I have the honour to report to the Department that His Grace must have been mis-informed in this matter as the Indians do not wish to rob the building of its semi-sacred character, they only ask the privilege of holding their meetings of the council in the building as they have not any other place to meet in council. After each council meeting the building has been cleaned and everything left in perfect order.

I might say for the information of the Department that it is not the Indians that want to use the building for council meetings only, but it is the Missionaries that are trying to prevent the Indians from holding any council meetings in this building and wish to use it for church purposes only, and the teacher in charge of the school at Whitefish River, who is acting as Anglican Missionary among the Indians, has gone so far as to lock the building in order to prevent the Indians from making use of it for council meetings.

As far as I can see there should not be reason why the building should not be available for the use of the Missionary for church services and the Indians for meetings of council, and the Indians are perfectly willing to abide by that decision.

Your obedient servant,

Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa, 3 April 1890

I have been directed by the Secretary of State to make arrangements for the erection of a new building at the Department of Indian Affairs. The building will be constructed of brick and will be completed in time for the opening of the new session of Parliament. The cost of the building is estimated at $5,000.

I have also been directed to make arrangements for the purchase of land adjacent to the building site. The land will be purchased from Mr. Smith, who has offered to sell it for $2,000.

I am instructed to proceed with the necessary steps to ensure that the building will be completed in time for the opening of the new session of Parliament.

I am directed to forward this memorandum to the Secretary of State for his approval.

THE SECRETARY,

With reference to the application of His Lordship
the Bishop of Algonquin for the opening of a school for a
portion of the Indians of the Whitefish River Band who
live about ten miles from Birch Island
on the Whitefish River near some of the Georgian Bay,
I have to say that there is no present a school at Birch
Island under the auspices of the Church of England.

According to the report for the September quarter received
from Mr. J.H. Watts, there are 11 children
in the roll, with an average attendance of 4. The
salary, which is voted, is $200.

In his annual report Superintendent Ross does not
mention the portion of the Band settled at the point in
question. Speaking of the Band generally he says:
"The Indians have a good school and the general profi-
ciency of the pupils is satisfactory".

If the school at Birch Island, which has been es-
tablished for some years at a point suitable for the
majority of the Whitefish Band has an attendance of only
4, it is hardly likely that a new school for the conven-
ience of only a portion of the Band would have a suffi-
cient attendance to warrant its being established.

H.C. Ross
Ottawa, 14th December, 1896.

Right Reverend Sir:

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the 25th ultimo, in regard to the establishment of a second school for the same number of six families of the Matapedia River Band who have settled on the Matapedia River four miles from the school at Birch Island.

In reply I have to say that the school already established at a point suitable for a capacity of the Band, although in operation for some years, has only 11 pupils on the rolls, with an average attendance of 4. It is not anticipated likely that a second school would be attended sufficient to justify its establishment.

I regret, therefore, that the Department does not see its way to increasing the number of schools for the Matapedia Band at present.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Sir,

A communication has been received from Chief Mr. McGregor, of the Whitefish River Reserve, in which he states as follows:

"Lately a man came and ordered the schoolhouse to be closed and prevented the members of the band from holding our council meetings and informed us that the old schoolhouse was sufficient to hold our council meetings."

Sir:

In reply to Official Letter of the 7th ultimo, in regard to a complaint made by Chief William McGregor, of the Whitefish River Reserve, that the schoolhouse was ordered to be closed and prevent meetings of the band from holding their council meetings, and in reply I have the honour to report that I visited Whitefish River and made an examination of the matter and found that there are two Indian members of the Anglican church who object to the holding of council meetings as they claim that it was erected for a schoolhouse and church, and not a building to hold public meetings where the Indians sit and smoke and ruin the floor and furniture, and do not assist in scrubbing or cleaning after their council meetings.

My dear Mr. Scott:

Ever since I became Bishop of the Diocese of Algoma, twenty-six years ago, we have had the use of a small building at Birch Island, part of the Whitefish Indian Reserve. The Indians at that point are divided between the Church of England and the Roman Catholic Communion. There is a disposition at the present time to claim the building for use by the band as a council chamber. This is not at all satisfactory to us, as it interferes with our use of it for religious purposes. Will you kindly tell me the history of this building, and what rights the Church of England has in it. One of the oldest residents declares that the materials were provided by the Church, and that it is to the best of his knowledge and belief a church building. Of course, if it is a Government building the Department has a right to determine what its uses shall be; nevertheless, after so long a period of use, some clear and generous rights should belong to the Church of England, her use of it having been unbroken through the period referred to. Will you kindly let me have an answer at your earliest convenience.

Believe me,

Very faithfully yours,

George Algoma.

Sir:

I am in receipt of Official Letter of the 4th instant, in regard to the report made to the Department by His Grace the Archbishop of Algoma in reference to the building at Birch Island which for some years past was used as a combined church and school, and in reply I have the honour to report to the Department that His Grace must have been mis-informed in this matter as the Indians do not wish to rob the building of its semi-sacred character; they only ask the privilege of holding their meetings or the council in the building as they have not any other place to meet in council. After each council meeting the building has been cleaned and everything left in perfect order.

I might say for the information of the Department that it is not the Indians that want to use the building for council meetings only, but it is the Missionaries that are trying to prevent the Indians from holding any council meetings in this building and wish to use it for church purposes only, and the teacher in charge of the school at Whitefish River, who is acting as Anglican Missionary among the Indians, has gone so far as to lock the building in order to prevent the Indians from making use of it for council meetings.

As far as I can see there should not be reason why the building should not be available for the use of the Missionary for church services and the Indians for meetings of council, and the Indians are perfectly willing to abide by that decision.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
